Today was a truly special day in Moyale as we embarked on an entourage through Moyale town, marking Day 63 of the Horn of Africa Elephant Campaign Walk.

 I am thrilled to announce that the Elephant Campaign team has reached the Ethiopia border in Moyale, a significant milestone in our journey.

 I want to extend my heartfelt thanks to the entire team that accompanied me today: ACC Moyale, Mr. Martin Muhia; the KWS team led by Warden Mr. Abdi Kampicha; OCPD Mr. George Kipkoros; AP Commander (PPU) Mr. Shadrack Yego; Deputy Officer in Charge of Moyale Prison, Mr. Kodeck Mose; Deputy OCS, Mr. Samora Bala; Subcounty AP Commander, Mr. Geoffrey Elongi; the KDF team led by Lieutenant Mr. M. Kassim; Border Liaison Officer, Major Ruto; the Peace Forum team led by Chair Mr. Mohamed; and the Dabel Conservancy team led by Mr. Ali Bule.

Walking through Moyale town and engaging with the residents was a powerful experience. It was an opportunity to share the message of conservation with the local community and to emphasize the importance of protecting our wildlife and environment. 

The presence of local leaders and security personnel made the day even more impactful, as it demonstrated a unified effort between different sectors of society‚Äîgovernment, security forces, and conservationists‚Äîworking together toward a common goal.

After the walk, I, along with KWS Warden Mr. Abdi Kampicha, had the pleasure of inviting the entire team to the KWS camp for lunch. 

Sharing a meal together was more than just an act of hospitality; it was a moment to reflect on and celebrate the progress we have made so far in the Elephant Campaign Walk. It allowed us to  strengthen our bonds, and appreciate the collective effort that has brought us this far.

Eating together symbolizes unity and the importance of working as a team to achieve common goals. It was a time to not only celebrate our accomplishments but also to recharge and prepare for the journey ahead, knowing that every step we take is a step toward securing a future where both people and wildlife can thrive. @KWSKenya

#Ethiopia: #ENDF, #Amhara admin vow to ‚Äòintensify operations‚Äô against armed groups and figures embedded within gov‚Äôt

The Ethiopian National Defense Force (ENDF) and the Amhara regional government announced they will continue what they describe as "law enforcement operations" until "peace is fully restored," despite ongoing conflict in the region for the past 14 months.  In a press briefing on 01 October, Mengesha Fentahun, head of the Amhara Communication Bureau, said the operations will target "armed groups and leaders within government structures" and will be "intensified."

Colonel Getnet Adane, head of ENDF Public Relations, reiterated that the military is working "in collaboration with the regional government" to address those "causing disruption." He noted that previous efforts involving "dialogue" with local communities have "not always been fully successful." Additionally, he mentioned that "urban cells" have been "relocating to rural areas" and spreading "false information" on social media.

According to some historical accounts "since the 12th century, ...Ethiopian kings have warned ...Egyptian sultans of their power to divert waters of the Nile, often in response to religious conflicts. In one version of history, these gifts even included a fragment of the True Cross of Christ, which was historically believed to have been found by Empress Helena. This relic of the cross is celebrated by Ethiopian Orthodox believers during the festival of Gishen Mariam.
Today, #Ethiopia has built the GER-Dam and, with it, Ethiopia can physically control the Blue Nile Gorge,-86% source of most of the Nile waters. its not hypothetical anymore! Lions Save Girl From Kidnappers

A 12-year-old girl was
walking home from school in Ethiopia when she was attacked
and kidnapped by four men.

They intended to sell her into a forced marriage. 

A week later, with the police in pursuit, the kidnappers were
attempting to move her to a new location when a pride of lions heard her cries for and rushed in.

The three lions chased off the men and sat quietly with the girl until the police arrived, then disappeared back into the brush. 

"They stood guard until we found her and then they just left her like a gift and went back into the forest," said
Sergeant Wondmu Wedaj. 

She told the authorities that while her kidnappers had beaten her, the
animals had never threatened her.

Are animals more compassionate than some humans?

General Michael Langley, the head of AFRICOM operations, addressed the rising insecurity in East Africa, particularly in Somalia. He pointed out the challenges between the federal governments of Somalia and Ethiopia regarding the contribution of forces and expressed hope that they would resolve their indifference. He highlighted the recent achievements of the Somali government against the terrorist group Al-Shabaab in the southern and central regions. Furthermore, he expressed concern about the growing presence of ISIS in the northern regions, especially Puntland and Somaliland. He believes that the Somali National Army is capable of carrying out offensive operations and maintaining control over liberated areas. The US government role is to advise and assist the Somali government in tackling terrorist threats. He is optimistic about the professionalism and training the Somali National Army is receiving, as well as the ongoing stabilization plans following liberation.

The Ethiopian Bible is the oldest, original and most complete bible on earth. Written in Ge‚Äôez an ancient language of Ethiopia, it‚Äôs nearly 800 years older than the King James Version and contains 81-88 books compared to 66.   

Written on goat skin in the early Ethiopian language of Ge‚Äôez. It is also World‚Äôs first illustrated Christian Bible. It includes the Book of EN0CH, Esdras, Buruch and all 3 Books of MACCABEE, and a host of others that was excommunicated from the KJV.

The Ethiopian bible dating analysis dated Garima 2 to be written around 390-570, and Garima 1 from 530-660. During the Italian invasion fire was set in the monastery in the 1930s to destroy the monastery‚Äôs church nevertheless the Bible survive.

The original Christianity of Egypt was established by the apostle Mark in AD 42 in Ethiopia (Coptic Church--Coptic Orthodox Christianity) where it spread to Europe and some part of Asia. Today We have been told Christianity came from Rome.

The Catholic Church begin with the teachings of Yeshua (Yeh≈çshu'a) who lived in the 1st century CE in the province of Judea of the Roman Empire. Meanwhile by AD 313, the Roman Empire Catholic Church faced persecution and christianity was not openly practice, the Coptic Orthodox Christianity was flourishing in the Aksumite Empire now in Ethiopia.

Church of Our Lady Mary of Zion Axum Ethiopia,  houses the Ark of the Covenant, bears a design similar to that of Eastern Orthodox churches in Europe. Its most recent building, reconstructed in the 1950s, has a dome similar to the Hagia Sophia in Istanbul. It is heavily guarded.

Lalibela is a holy town most famous for its churches carved from the living rock, which play an important part in the history of rock-cut architecture. Its buildings, built in the 11th and 12th centuries, are considered symbolic representations of biblical Jerusalem.

For early Christians, the risk of persecution from the Romans sometimes ran high, forcing them to practice their beliefs in private, posing a challenge for those scholars who study this era.

The King James Version Bible New Testament which is said to be translated from Greek, and the Old Testament from Hebrew and Aramaic, and the Apocrypha from Greek and Latin, All were originally translated from the Ethiopian bible. original Greek Bible was written around AD 1500.

It is also known that Ancient Afrikans of Old Egypt (Kemet) studied this bible in their temple which was known as the "The Book of the Coming Forth by Day and Night". The original Bible was produced by Black Afrikans approximately 3,400 years.

Before the Old Testament and more than 4,200 years before the New Testament, and countless versions of it have been written and published. Different scholars also translated the bible to their local languages during their studies in Kemet.

‚ÄúI was born Jewish in a small village in Ethiopia. I never knew my father. When I was five years old, my mother and I were set to move to Israel. It had always been her dream. A week before the flight, my mother died in a car accident. I couldn‚Äôt move to Israel on my own because I was too young. I was adopted by my father‚Äôs sister, a Christian. 
Throughout my childhood I always knew I was Jewish, and dreamt of one day moving to Israel. 
Around the age of 18 (I never knew my birthday), I decided to fulfill my mother‚Äôs dream and finally move to Israel.
I came here all on my own. After two years in Israel, I joined the army. The day I put on my uniform for the first time was one of the proudest days of my life. At that moment, I knew I made it. 
My dream is to help other orphans like myself. I know how hard it is to grow up without parents, and how important it is to have supportive people by your side. But if you believe in yourself and work hard - nothing can stop you.‚Äù

- Pvt. Minalu, an IDF Security Center Specialist.

Did you know?

A new ocean is forming in Africa along a 35-mile crack that opened up in Ethiopia in 2005. 

The crack, which has been expanding ever since, is a result of three tectonic plates pulling away from each other. 

It‚Äôs thought that Africa‚Äôs new ocean will take at least 5 million to 10 million years to form, but the Afar region‚Äôs fortuitous location at the boundaries of the Nubian, Somali and Arabian plates makes it a unique laboratory to study elaborate tectonic processes.

There are still some big unknowns, including what is causing the continent to rift apart. Some think that a massive plume of superheated rocks rising from the mantle beneath East Africa could be driving the region‚Äôs continental rift.

Each plate boundary in the Afar region is spreading at different speeds, but the combined forces of these separating plates is creating what‚Äôs known as a mid-ocean ridge system, where eventually a new ocean will form.

The three plates are separating at different speeds. The Arabian plate is moving away from Africa at a rate of about 1 inch per year, while the two African plates are separating even slower, between half an inch to 0.2 inches per year.

A bus swerved into a river in southern Ethiopia on Wednesday, killing at least 28 people and seriously injuring 19 others, local authorities said.

The incident happened in Wolaita, which lies about 400 kilometres (around 250 miles) south of the capital Addis Ababa.

"So far, 28 people have died in the accident and 19 others have been seriously injured," local authorities said on Facebook.

There was little additional information, including the total number of passengers on board, but the authorities said search operations were continuing.

#Ethiopia: #NBE licenses first five independent forex bureaus, permitting cash only foreign exchange transactions

The National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE) has announced the issuance of operational licenses to five independent foreign exchange bureaus, following their compliance with the bank‚Äôs Foreign Exchange Directive No. FXD/01/2024.

The newly licensed bureaus are Dugda Fidelity Investment PLC, Ethio Independent Foreign Exchange Bureau, Global Independent Foreign Exchange Bureau, Robust Independent Foreign Exchange Bureau, and Yoga Forex Bureau.

In a statement, the NBE highlighted the significance of these new entities in enhancing Ethiopia's foreign exchange market. "These forex bureaus will play a crucial role in expanding the market by handling the buying and selling of major convertible currencies, strictly through cash note transactions," the NBE said. 

NBE's decision to grant this licenses to comes shortly after the National Bank announced that it would begin accepting applications for such entities, in line with the 29 July new directive allowing independent stakeholders to trade in Forex

The bureaus are authorized to conduct spot transactions with immediate delivery of the currencies involved, while activities such as issuing Letters of Credit for imports and exports remain restricted to banks.

According to the NBE, the bureaus are permitted to purchase up to $10,000 of foreign currency from customers without requiring customs declarations, with higher amounts permissible upon presentation of such documentation. For sales, the limit is set at $5,000 for personal travel and $10,000 for business travel, provided the necessary travel documents are presented.

The move to allow forex trade outside of banks is part of the recent macroeconomic package the country has adopted, aimed at opening up Ethiopia‚Äôs financial sector and aligning it with global practices.

#Ethiopia: Conflict halts schooling for millions in #Amhara; students abandon classrooms for safety

The Amhara Education Bureau reports that only two million students have registered for the current academic year, falling short of the anticipated seven million enrollments. Parents and students in rural areas of Amhara have reported widespread school closures and educational disruptions due to security concerns.

Students from various districts described schools being closed, repurposed as military camps, or damaged in the conflict. The ongoing clashes between federal forces and non-state Fano militias have created a precarious security situation, impeding the development of infrastructure and essential services. This continues a trend from the previous year, when millions of students were unable to attend school due to the conflict.

U.S. Ambassador to Ethiopia, Ervin Massinga, has highlighted a dire educational crisis in the Amhara Region, where, according to UN OCHA data, 4,178 schools are now closed due to the ongoing conflict initiated by the OPDO/PP-led Ethiopian government against the Amhara community. This conflict has resulted in the educational displacement of approximately 4.1 million children, representing not just a current crisis but a future challenge for Ethiopia's development. @hrw @amnesty @antonioguterres @RepJames

#AmharaConcentrationCamps, reminiscent of Auschwitz, are being secretly established throughout the Amhara region. One of the leaders of the Amhara Fano in Gojam, Asres Mare, recently revealed alarming details on his social media. He reports that the oppressive regime of Abiy Ahmed, having faced repeated military defeats, is now employing terroristic tactics by abducting innocent civilians from cities and detaining them in these camps.

The regime has issued directives to remove regional police and security forces from major cities, including Bahir Dar, and replace them with a covert force disguised as federal police. This plan is set to take effect immediately, with around 200 members of this repressive unit already deployed in Bahir Dar. Innocent civilians are being targeted for abduction, and even regional police officers have become victims of this crackdown.

We urgently call on the international community to recognize and act against these grave human rights violations. These actions are the hallmark of state-sponsored terrorism and are leading to the imprisonment of innocent people in secret #AmharaConcentrationCamps. The silence of the world will only embolden this regime. Immediate intervention is needed to stop these atrocities and protect the Amhara civilians from further persecution.

#Ethiopia: Conflict halts schooling for millions in #Amhara; students abandon classrooms for safety

The Amhara Education Bureau reports that only two million students have registered for the current academic year, falling short of the anticipated seven million enrollments. Parents and students in rural areas of Amhara have reported widespread school closures and educational disruptions due to security concerns.

Students from various districts described schools being closed, repurposed as military camps, or damaged in the conflict. The ongoing clashes between federal forces and non-state Fano militias have created a precarious security situation, impeding the development of infrastructure and essential services. This continues a trend from the previous year, when millions of students were unable to attend school due to the conflict.

Alert: Tedros Adhanom: WHO chief may face genocide charges

Former Terrorist Dr Tedros who is not a medical doctor but is a former member of the Tigray Peoples liberation front-a highly violet terrorist organisation and on the proscribed list of banned terror organisations in the US is still under threat of genocide charges.

The puppet who fronts Bill Gates and his dodgy ideologies through the WHO is also accused of corruption with the Chinese Communist Party and has been accused of sexual deviancy.

So just why did they think this man should have access to our medical data?

Well Bill Gates has a lot of money and the politicians in our respective countries just love Bill Gates money.

An American economist nominated for the Nobel peace prize has called for the head of the World Health Organisation to be prosecuted for genocide over his alleged involvement in directing Ethiopia‚Äôs security forces.

David Steinman accused Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, 55, who took over at the WHO three years ago, of being one of three officials in control of the Ethiopian security services from 2013 to 2015.

Dr Tedros was the country‚Äôs health minister from 2005 to 2012 and its foreign minister until 2016, when his Tigray People‚Äôs Liberation Front party was the main member of the ruling coalition.

Mr Steinman, an economist and campaigner nominated for the peace prize last year, lodged the complaint at the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

He claimed that Dr Tedros ‚Äúwas a crucial decision maker in relation to security service actions that included killing, arbitrarily detaining and torturing Ethiopians‚Äù.

Dr Tedros has risen to international prominence as the leader of the UN‚Äôs health body during the coronavirus pandemic. He is the organisation‚Äôs first leader without medical qualifications.

The complaint to prosecutors at the ICC comes after General Berhanu Jula, Ethiopia‚Äôs army chief of staff, called last month for the WHO leader to resign. He accused him of trying to procure weapons for the Tigray region, where the Ethiopian army is fighting local forces.

In his complaint, Mr Steinman pointed to a 2016 US government report on human rights in Ethiopia that found the ‚Äúcivilian authorities at times did not maintain control over the security forces, and local police in rural areas and local militias sometimes acted independently‚Äù.

Mr Steinman added that the US report cited ‚Äúother documented crimes‚Äù. He accused Dr Tedros of being involved in the ‚Äúintimidation of opposition candidates and supporters‚Äù, including ‚Äúarbitrary arrest . . . and lengthy pre-trial detention‚Äù.

The complaint also alleged that Dr Tedros oversaw the ‚Äúkilling, and causing serious bodily and mental harm to, members of the Amhara, Konso, Oromo and Somali tribes with intent to destroy those tribes in whole or in part‚Äù.

Mr Steinman claimed that during the four years Dr Tedros ‚Äúco-led‚Äù Ethiopia‚Äôs government, the regime ‚Äúwas marked by widespread or systematic crimes against humanity by subordinates‚Äù. His complaint can proceed only if it is adopted by prosecutors at The Hague court, which is independent of the UN. If they do, it would be the first prosecution of a senior UN figure.

Mr Steinman, a former consultant to the US National Security Council, was a senior foreign adviser to Ethiopia‚Äôs democracy movement for 27 years until its victory in 2018 under Abiy Ahmed Ali, the current prime minister.

Dr Tedros has denied the allegations and any wrongdoing. He issued a statement last month regarding the current situation in Tigray. ‚ÄúThere have been reports suggesting I am taking sides in this situation,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis is not true and I want to say that I am on only one side and that is the side of peace.‚Äù

The incredible site of the mountain church, Abuna Yemata Guh, is a monolithic church located in the Hawzen woreda of the Tigray Region, Ethiopia. It is situated at a height of 2,580 meters (8,460 ft).

According to local tradition, the church was built in the sixth century by one of the Nine Saints, Abuna Yemata. The Nine Saints are said to have come to Ethiopia from various regions, including Rome, Constantinople, and Syria, to spread Christianity and establish a monastic tradition. The paintings in the church are original and have been well-preserved due to the dry air and lack of humidity.

To access the church, one must climb a steep cliff with hand and feet holes carved into it. The ascent is considered hazardous and requires both physical strength and mental fortitude. Abuna Yemata Guh is one of 35 churches in Ethiopia that is built into a high place, making it a unique and awe-inspiring site to visit.

full_text:
Ethiopia's 'Abuna Yemata Guh' is arguably the most inaccessible place of worship on earth and has to be climbed on foot to reach. Located in the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia, this ancient rock-hewn church stands atop a vertical cliff, perched at an elevation of around 2,580 meters (8,460 feet). It is considered one of the most inaccessible and challenging religious sites to reach in the world.

The construction of rock-hewn churches in Ethiopia has a long history dating back to the 4th century AD, during the time of the Aksumite Empire. These churches were built by carving into solid rock formations, creating impressive architectural masterpieces. The rock-hewn churches served as centers of religious devotion and provided shelter during times of conflict.

Abuna Yemata Guh is believed to have been carved out of the cliff face during the 5th century, making it over 1,500 years old. It is dedicated to Saint Yemata, a legendary Ethiopian saint who is said to have meditated and prayed in this secluded location. The church is named after Abuna (meaning "father" in Amharic) Yemata, who was a prominent Ethiopian religious leader.

What makes Abuna Yemata Guh particularly notable is the challenging ascent required to reach it. Pilgrims and visitors must hike up a steep and narrow footpath, navigating rugged terrain and exposed ledges. The ascent involves scrambling up the cliff face, sometimes using ropes for support. This arduous journey symbolizes a spiritual pilgrimage, testing the devotion and commitment of those seeking solace and connection with their faith.

Despite its remote and inaccessible location, Abuna Yemata Guh has attracted attention in recent years as a testament to Ethiopia's rich cultural heritage and architectural prowess. It is not only a place of worship but also a symbol of the enduring faith and determination of the Ethiopian people.

Furthermore, the Tigray region, where Abuna Yemata Guh is situated, has witnessed significant historical and cultural events throughout the centuries. It has been a center of religious and political power, with various empires and kingdoms rising and falling in the region. Today, Tigray is home to a diverse population, including the Tigrayan people, who have their unique language, culture, and traditions.

In recent years, the Tigray region has faced challenging times due to internal conflicts and humanitarian crises, making access to sites like Abuna Yemata Guh more difficult. Nevertheless, the church continues to be a testament to Ethiopia's rich history and the resilience of its people, reminding us of the enduring power of faith and the importance of preserving cultural heritage.

Oromo "Sefu" 

'Sefu' is where social order is expected among Oromos. Personality traits: Attitudes and behavior. Sefu is a social concept that separates what is shameful from what is not. It is the basis of the Oromo community; that is, it is possible! 

In this sociological conception, there is an unwritten but known law of what a healthy interaction of people with society should look like. A system has been set for how the powerful should use their power and how the powerful should help the weak. In this sense, it is a broad consciousness. 

The Oromo Sefu believes that Waqa, the creator of all, is the law of social order given to human beings since the world's creation. In ancient Oromo society belief, it is believed that every creature has its ayyaana (spirit). Thus, each creature (human, animal, plant, etc.) has distinguishing characteristics. When the creator created the earth, he made laws for man to live in order. These laws are called the law of man, the law of cattle, the law of horses, the law of wild animals, the law of plants, and the law of the sun and stars. 

"Sefu" is an immutable law of the creator. This includes killing, stealing, adultery, and lying, which are forbidden. Respecting the Creator, the Earth, and all other creatures is to respect the Law of the Creator. Prohibitions are enacted to protect the so-called 'legitimate' activities of society. A person is said to have committed a sin when he violates/transgresses these laws and prohibitions of the Creator. 

Sefu is a scale. The great and the small, the rich and the poor, and the enslaver and the enslaved are equal to each other. Sefu is a balance, but that doesn't mean it puts everyone on an equal footing. The landing zone is separated by weight. Sefu is not an idea that allows the joining and merging of two sides. 

In the Oromo community, people are measured by their Sefu. Respecting elders, respecting and obeying parents, etc., is widespread. It is said that they are vast when faced with issues beyond the human mind. Sefu is not a single idea that can be defined in one sentence. When Oromo says something like "safuu dha" (it is Sefu), it has many meanings. 

One can use sefu to express surprise, fear, pain, sadness, or shame. "Oromoon safuu qaba." It is said to express this idea.

"Oromo is now ruling over Ethiopia...We are the ones who created Ethiopia...Now we have the ownership of the country. We Oromos will lead this resource rich country and fix it. Any Oromo that opposes this point of view is a traitor and we will wipe them out." ~ Field Marshal Berhanu Jula, Chief of Staff of the Ethiopian National Defense Force (ENDF)

This was an impromptu speech made by Field Marshal Berhanu Jula two days ago (September 24, 2024) where he boasts about Oromo dominance and control over Ethiopia. He asserts that the Oromo are the rightful rulers of Ethiopia and claims that the Oromo have liberated themselves from oppression and now own the country. He states that enemies from different directions are rising up on Oromos, now that Oromos are ruling #Ethiopia at the top.

This is the mindset of the man who is leading the Ethiopian National Defense Force in its genocidal #WarOnAmhara for over a year.

Full Translation of Speech:

"Oromo is now ruling over Ethiopia, any Oromo who opposes this government is a traitor and we will eliminate them. We are the ones who created Ethiopia, and we are the ones who maintained Ethiopia. Through our struggle we have broken the chains that enslaved us and have freed ourselves. Oromo is again in power. Oromo are a great people who founded Ethiopia and brought Ethiopia to where it is today but even after doing this Oromo were never respected. Oromo have many heroes, these heroes founded this country and brought her to where she is now. As for us, we have broken the chains that had bound us through our struggle and have freed ourselves. Now we have the ownership of the country. We Oromos will lead this resource rich country and fix it. Any Oromo that opposes this point of view is a traitor and we will wipe them out. Our right is now respected, and we will slowly fix any issues. The people (Oromo) know this and that is why they are waiting patiently. The others (OLA) have to come to their senses and stop dividing the people. Every Oromo cares for every Oromo. Any Oromo that stands against Oromo is a traitor. Right when Oromo get our share and start ruling Ethiopia at the top, enemies from different directions are rising up on us. They'll disappear when we eliminate our traitors (OLA)." ~ Field Marshal Berhanu Jula, Chief of Staff of the Ethiopian National Defense Force (ENDF)

Safiri Nasi clients enjoying a boat ride at lake Hawassa. 

Lake Hawassa or Awasa, is an endorheic basin in Sidama Region of Ethiopia, located in the Main Ethiopian Rift south of Addis Ababa, the capital city of the country. According to the Statistical Abstract of Ethiopia for 1967/68, the lake is 16 km long and 9 km wide, with a surface area of 129 square kilometers.
